Most of the bottom of the ocean is still a mystery, and space – with all its planets and stars – is the brand new "terra incognita" for explorers today and in the future.

slides.prompt:
Create a THREE-PANEL EVOLVING MAP:
Panel 1: 'Before Exploration (1400)' — Draw what Europeans knew: Europe, parts of Africa and Asia. Leave the rest blank or write 'terra incognita' and draw sea monsters.
Panel 2: 'During Exploration (1500)' — Add the Americas (rough outlines), Africa's coast, and ocean routes.
Panel 3: 'After Exploration (1550)' — Draw all continents, the Pacific Ocean, major routes.
Label each explorer's contribution!
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to be the mapmaker! You're going to create a special three-part map showing how our world's map grew. For the first part, draw what people knew ages ago. For the second part, add the new lands and oceans explorers discovered around the year 1500. And for the third part, draw the whole world as we know it after lots of exploring, including big oceans and all the continents. Don't forget to label who discovered what!

slides.text: Maps tell the story of human knowledge — what we knew, when we learned it, and what we still do not know. The Age of Exploration transformed our maps from showing a small fraction of the world to showing nearly all of it. Every explorer added a piece to the puzzle. And the story continues: ocean floors, other planets, and the universe beyond are today's terra incognita.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child describe how world maps changed during the Age of Exploration, identify specific explorers' contributions to geographic knowledge, and create maps showing the evolution of geographic understanding?
slides.mascot_explanation: We did it! You've just finished creating your own evolving map, showing exactly how explorers from long ago helped us learn about our planet. You saw how maps went from showing just a little bit of the world to almost all of it, and you even learned that exploring isn't over – there are still mysterious places like the deep ocean and outer space waiting for us!

parent_notes: Historical maps are fascinating visual primary sources that children love to examine. The evolution from medieval maps (with sea monsters and terra incognita) to accurate world maps within a single century is a powerful story of human curiosity and courage. Print the historical maps large enough for the child to study details. The three-panel activity produces an impressive display piece. The connection to modern unmapped areas (ocean floor, space) helps children see that exploration continues. Maps also raise important questions about perspective and power: Who makes the maps? Whose point of view do they represent? Why is North 'up'? These are seeds of critical geographic thinking.

title: Light — Shadows, Sundials, and Telling Time by the Sun
description: Students investigate how shadows change throughout the day as the sun moves across the sky. They build a simple sundial and learn that ancient people used shadows to tell time. They connect light properties from the week to practical applications.
instructions:
1. Review the week's light topics: refraction, color, spectrum.
2. Today: light travels in straight lines, which creates SHADOWS.
3. Go outside and observe shadows. Where is the sun? Where are the shadows?
4. Shadows are longest in morning and evening, shortest at noon. Why?
5. Ancient people used this pattern to tell time: the SUNDIAL.
6. Build a simple sundial: stick in clay, mark shadow positions hourly.
7. Discuss how sundials work: the shadow moves as the sun moves.
8. Compare the sundial to a clock: both measure time, different technology.
9. Record shadow observations in science journal.
10. Week review: What have we learned about light?

slides.heading: Shadows and Sundials
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the title page for our super cool science adventure today! It tells us we're going to learn all about shadows and how people used the sun to tell time a long, long time ago with something called a sundial.

items: Clay or playdough for secure base
Paper plate or large piece of cardboard
Pencil and marker for marking positions
slides.setup_instructions: This lesson requires sunlight — plan for a sunny day or reschedule if cloudy. Set up the sundial base outdoors in an open area. The ideal approach is to mark the shadow position every hour throughout the day, but even 3-4 marks over the lesson period demonstrate the principle.
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, let's get our materials ready for our sundial! We need a stick that will be like the pointer, some sticky clay to hold it up, a plate to put it on, and a pencil or marker to draw our time lines. We'll also need our science journal to write things down, and if we have a compass, that can help us figure out which way is which outside! Make sure you have a sunny spot ready to go for this.

slides.text: This week we explored refraction, color, and the spectrum. Today we investigate another property of light: it travels in STRAIGHT LINES. This is why shadows exist! When light hits an opaque object (one you cannot see through), the light cannot bend around it. A dark area forms on the other side — a SHADOW. Shadows are evidence of light's straight-line travel.
slides.mascot_explanation: This part explains something really important about light: it travels in super straight lines, like a laser beam! When light bumps into something it can't go through, like your body or a toy, it makes a dark shape on the other side – that's a shadow! So, shadows are like proof that light is always going straight.

slides.text: Go outside and observe your shadow. Point to the sun (never look directly at it!). Your shadow points the OPPOSITE direction. Now notice: in the morning, the sun is low in the east, so shadows are long and point west. At noon, the sun is high overhead, so shadows are short. In the evening, the sun is low in the west, so shadows are long and point east.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, time to go outside and be shadow detectives! Find the sun in the sky – but don't look right at it, that's too bright! See how your shadow is pointing in the opposite direction of the sun? In the morning and evening, when the sun is low, your shadow will be super long, but around lunchtime, when the sun is high up, your shadow will be much shorter.

slides.text: Ancient Egyptians, Greeks, and Romans noticed this daily shadow pattern thousands of years ago. They invented the SUNDIAL — a device that tells time using shadows. A stick (called a gnomon) casts a shadow on a flat surface. As the sun moves across the sky, the shadow moves like the hand of a clock. In fact, clock hands were invented to IMITATE the shadow on a sundial!
slides.mascot_explanation: Isn't it neat that people figured out how to tell time using just shadows? Long ago, before we had clocks, people noticed that shadows changed throughout the day, just like we saw outside. They invented a sundial, which is basically a stick in the ground that casts a shadow, and they marked where the shadow fell at different times to know what time it was.

slides.text: Let us build a sundial! Push a stick straight up in clay on a paper plate. Place it in the sun. Every hour, mark where the shadow falls and write the time. By the end of the day, you will have a working sundial! Tomorrow you could check: does the shadow fall on the same marks at the same times? It should — because the sun follows the same path.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we get to build our very own sundial! Take your stick and push it firmly into the clay, making sure it stands up straight. Then, put your plate in a sunny spot outside, and we'll mark where the shadow is right now. We'll come back later to mark it again and watch how the shadow moves!

slides.prompt: Build your sundial and mark the first shadow position with the current time. While waiting for the shadow to move, explore shadows: 1) Move closer and farther from a wall — how does your shadow size change? 2) Use two light sources — can you make TWO shadows? 3) Draw your shadow outline on the ground with chalk. 4) In your journal, draw a diagram explaining why shadows form (straight-line light + opaque object = shadow). 5) Write a summary of everything you learned about light this week: refraction, color/spectrum, and shadows.
slides.mascot_explanation: This is where the fun really happens – building and playing with our sundial! First, stick your pole in the clay and mark the shadow with today's time. Then, while we wait for the shadow to move, you can do some cool shadow experiments like seeing how your shadow changes when you move closer or farther away, or even draw your shadow on the ground! Don't forget to draw a picture in your journal explaining how shadows happen and write down all the neat things we learned about light this week.

slides.text: This week we discovered that light refracts through different materials, that white light is actually all colors mixed together, and that light's straight-line travel creates shadows that humans have used to tell time for thousands of years. Light is essential for life — plants use it for food, our eyes use it for seeing, and our ancestors used it for timekeeping. Light truly illuminates our world in every sense!
slides.mastery_check: Can the child explain why shadows form, describe how shadow length and direction change throughout the day, build a functioning sundial, and summarize the week's light concepts?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, we did it! This week we learned that light bends, that it's made of all the colors of the rainbow, and how light traveling straight makes shadows that people used to tell time! It's amazing how light helps us see, grow food, and even understand the whole day. You really became a light expert!

parent_notes: The sundial project is most effective if you can mark shadow positions over several hours. Consider setting it up in the morning and checking it periodically throughout the day. The key insight — that clock hands imitate sundial shadows — connects ancient and modern technology beautifully. Shadow play is endlessly entertaining: children love tracing each other's shadows, making shadow puppets, and discovering that shadow size changes with distance from the light source. The week-end summary helps consolidate the three light lessons into a coherent understanding. If weather prevents outdoor work, use a flashlight and a stick to simulate sun movement indoors.

title: Rainbow Spectrum Art — Creating with Light and Color
description: Integrating science and art, students create artwork inspired by the color spectrum. They use watercolors or colored pencils to create a spectrum art piece, exploring color gradients, blending, and the relationship between science and artistic beauty.
instructions:
1. Review the visible spectrum from science class: ROY G. BIV.
2. Discuss how artists use color theory: warm vs. cool colors, complementary colors.
3. Demonstrate painting a smooth color gradient from red to violet.
4. Students choose a spectrum art project: rainbow landscape, spectrum animal, or abstract spectrum.
5. Practice blending adjacent colors smoothly.
6. Create the final artwork.
7. Discuss: Science tells us WHAT colors are; art shows us how BEAUTIFUL they are.
8. Display completed spectrum art.

slides.heading: Rainbow Spectrum Art
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at this! This slide is introducing our super fun project: Rainbow Spectrum Art! We're going to be artists and scientists all at once, using light and color to make something beautiful. Isn't it cool that we can explore science through art?

items: Watercolor paints with full color range
Watercolor paper or heavy drawing paper
slides.setup_instructions: This lesson integrates the science of light with artistic expression. Display the spectrum chart from science class. Demonstrate blending technique: paint one color, while still wet, add the adjacent color and let them meet in the middle. This creates a smooth gradient. Have reference images of spectrum art for inspiration.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, let's get our art supplies ready! We'll need watercolors that have all the rainbow colors, special watercolor paper that won't get too soggy, some brushes for painting, a cup for water to clean our brushes, and paper towels to dry them. We'll also use a pencil to lightly sketch our ideas first. Grab all these things so we can start creating!

slides.text: This week in science, you learned that white light contains ALL the colors of the rainbow: red, orange, yellow, green, blue, indigo, violet. Newton discovered this with a prism. Today we celebrate this discovery through ART — because the spectrum is not just scientifically interesting, it is breathtakingly BEAUTIFUL.
slides.mascot_explanation: Remember in science class when we learned about the rainbow colors: red, orange, yellow, green, blue, indigo, and violet? That's called the visible spectrum! Today, we're going to use those amazing colors to make art, because the way light makes a rainbow is not just science, it's also incredibly beautiful to look at.

slides.text: Artists organize colors using the COLOR WHEEL — which is the spectrum bent into a circle. WARM colors (red, orange, yellow) feel energetic and bright. COOL colors (green, blue, violet) feel calm and peaceful. Colors opposite each other on the wheel (like red and green, or blue and orange) are COMPLEMENTARY — they make each other pop when placed side by side.
slides.mascot_explanation: Artists have special ways to think about colors, like using a color wheel! Warm colors, like reds and yellows, feel exciting and energetic, while cool colors, like blues and purples, feel calm and peaceful. Colors that are opposites on the wheel, like red and green, make each other look extra bright when they're next to each other!

slides.text: Today's technique: BLENDING. Instead of painting solid blocks of color, we will create smooth GRADIENTS where one color melts into the next — just like a real rainbow. Watch: I paint red, then while it is still wet, I add orange right next to it. The colors meet and blend smoothly. Then orange blends into yellow, yellow into green, and so on through the spectrum.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's learn a super cool painting trick called blending! Instead of painting solid stripes of color, we're going to make the colors melt into each other smoothly, just like in a real rainbow. Watch how I paint red, then add some orange right next to it while it's still wet, and they mix together perfectly. We'll do this for all the colors in the spectrum!

slides.text: Choose your project: 1) A RAINBOW LANDSCAPE — a scene where the sky or land is painted in spectrum colors. 2) A SPECTRUM ANIMAL — draw an animal outline and fill it with blended rainbow colors. 3) ABSTRACT SPECTRUM — create a free-form design using all the spectrum colors in creative arrangements. Each project celebrates the beauty of light and color!
slides.mascot_explanation: For our artwork, you get to pick what you want to make! You could draw a landscape, like a sky or hills, and paint it with all the rainbow colors. Or, you could draw an animal and fill it in with a beautiful spectrum of colors. If you want to be extra creative, you can make an abstract design with all the colors mixed up in fun ways!

slides.prompt: Create your spectrum art piece! Plan your design with a light pencil sketch. Then paint or color using all seven spectrum colors, blending them smoothly where they meet. Tips: work quickly with watercolors so colors blend while wet. Use enough water for smooth gradients. Let the first layer dry before adding details. When finished, write a title and a sentence explaining the connection between your art and the science of light.
slides.mascot_explanation: This is the exciting part – making your own spectrum art! First, lightly sketch your idea with your pencil. Then, use your watercolors to paint all the rainbow colors, making sure they blend smoothly into each other. Remember to work a little fast with watercolors so they mix nicely while they're wet. You've got this!

slides.text: Science and art are two ways of understanding the same beautiful world. Science explains WHAT light is — waves of different lengths that our eyes interpret as colors. Art shows us what those colors can DO — create beauty, express emotion, and capture our imagination. Your spectrum art is proof that science and art are not opposites; they are partners.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child use the full spectrum of colors in an artwork, blend adjacent colors smoothly, explain the connection between the visible spectrum and their art, and identify warm and cool colors?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did it! You've created your very own rainbow spectrum art! Science helps us understand *how* colors are made from light, but art shows us just how *beautiful* those colors can be. You used all the colors, blended them like a pro, and made something truly amazing that shows off the magic of light.

parent_notes: This integration of science and art demonstrates that learning is interconnected — a core Montessori principle. The spectrum art project makes the abstract science of light tangible and personal. Watercolor blending is a wonderful technique that produces stunning results even for beginners, because the water does much of the blending work. If your child prefers colored pencils, layering and blending with pressure also creates gradients. The warm/cool color distinction and complementary colors are foundational art concepts. Display the finished artwork prominently — it represents both scientific understanding and artistic expression.
